words.ENTRY: readverb(past, past participle read) to look at words and understand them: In their first years in school, children learn to read and write.Don't bother me. I'm reading.I just read a great book.

<H>really</H><audio>really.mp3</audio><PS>adverb</PS><NR>1.</NR><D>actually; in fact; truly:</D> <X>I couldn't believe it was really happening.</X><dot><X>She wasn't really mad. She was only pretending.</X><dot><X>Is it really true?</X><NR>2.</NR><D>very; very much:</D> <X>I'm really tired.</X><dot><X>He really enjoys his job.</X><dot><X>Are you really sure?</X><NR>3.</NR><D>(used as a question for expressing surprise, interest, doubt, etc.):</D> <X>"She left her husband." "Really? When did that happen?"</X><dot><X>"He's a very happy person." "Really? I've never seen him smile." </X><CF>not really</CF> <D>not completely:</D> <X>I'm not really sure this is the right way.</X><dot><X>"Did you have to wait a long time?" "No, not really."</X>

reasonnouncountable, uncountablereason (for something/for doing something); reason (why .../that ...)
the cause of something; something that explains why something happens or exists: countableWhat's your reason for being so late?She quit her job for personal reasons.

<H>red</H><su>1</su><audio>red.mp3</audio><PS>adjective</PS>(<DR>redder</DR>; <DR>reddest</DR>) <NR>1.</NR><D>of the color of blood:</D> <X>red wine</X><dot><X>The berries on that bush turn bright red in October.</X><NR>2.</NR><D>(used about a person's hair or an animal's fur) of a color between red, orange and brown:</D> <X>She has red hair and freckles.</X><H>red</H><su>2</su><audio>red.mp3</audio><PS>noun</PS><bracket>countable, uncountable</bracket><D>the color of blood:</D> <bracket>uncountable</bracket><X>She was dressed in red.</X> (= in red clothes)

<H>regular</H><audio>regular.mp3</audio><PS>adjective</PS><D>ordinary; without any special or extra features:</D> <X>Do you want regular or diet cola?</X><dot><X>I just want to buy a regular white shirt, nothing fancy.</X>

<H>relax</H><audio>relax.mp3</audio><PS>verb</PS><D>to make or become less worried or tense; to spend time not doing very much:</D> <X>This vacation will give you a chance to relax.</X><dot><X>A hot bath will relax you after a hard day's work.</X><dot><X>They spent the evening relaxing in front of the TV.</X>

<H>restaurant</H><audio>restaurant.mp3</audio><PS>noun</PS><bracket>countable</bracket><D>a place where you can buy and eat a meal:</D> <X>a fast-food restaurant</X><dot><X>Andy took me out to lunch at a Chinese restaurant.</X><dot><X>She works as a waitress in a local restaurant.</X>

ricenoununcountablethe grain from a plant grown in hot, wet lands, that we cook and eat: a bowl of ricebrown rice
boiled rice

rideverb(past rode; past participle ridden) 1.to sit on a bicycle, horse, etc. and be carried along, controlling its movements: I've never ridden on a horse.She jumped onto her motorcycle and rode away.I usually ride my bike to school.2.to travel as a passenger in a bus, car, etc.: He's been riding the city bus to work for years.

<H>right</H><su>1</su><audio>right.mp3</audio><PS>adjective</PS><NR>1.</NR><D>on or of the side of the body that faces east when a person is facing north; not left:</D> <X>Do you write with your right hand or your left?</X><dot><X>Your seats are on the right side of the plane.</X><NR>2.</NR><D>correct; true:</D> <X>Sorry, that's not the right answer.</X><dot><X>You're absolutely right: the movie does start at 7 o'clock.</X><NR>3.</NR><D>best; most suitable:</D> <X>I don't think this is the right color for the walls.</X><dot><X>I hope I made the right decision.</X><NR>4.</NR><D>(used about behavior/actions) good; fair or what the law allows:</D> <X>It's not right to pay people so little.</X><dot><X>It's never right to steal.</X><H>right</H><su>2</su><audio>right.mp3</audio><PS>adverb</PS><NR>1.</NR><D>to the right side; not left:</D> <X>Turn right at the traffic light.</X><NR>2.</NR><D>correctly; in a satisfactory way:</D> <X>Did I spell your name right?</X><dot><X>These shoes don't fit right.</X><NR>3.</NR><D>exactly:</D> <X>The bus was right on time.</X><dot><X>The accident happened right here.</X><NR>4.</NR><D>immediately:</D> <X>He left right after dinner.</X><dot><X>Wait here a minute. I'll be right back. </X><CF>right away</CF> <D>immediately; without any delay:</D> <X>I'll take care of that right away.</X><dot><X>I understood right away what she wanted me to do. </X><CF>right now</CF><NR>1.</NR><D>at this moment; exactly now:</D> <X>We can't discuss this right now.</X><NR>2.</NR><D>at the present time (when compared with the past or the future):</D> <X>She has no job right now.</X><H>right</H><su>3</su><audio>right.mp3</audio><PS>noun</PS><bracket>uncountable</bracket><D>the right side or direction; not left:</D> <X>We live in the first house on the right.</X><dot><X>If you look to your right, you will see the Rocky Mountains in the distance.</X>
ringverb(past rang; past participle rung) to make a sound like a bell or to cause something to make this sound: Is that the phone ringing?We rang the doorbell again and again, but nobody answered.

<H>river</H><audio>river.mp3</audio><PS>noun</PS><bracket>countable</bracket><D>a large natural stream of water that flows across the land:</D> <X>the Mississippi River</X><dot><X>a picnic on the bank of the river</X>
<H>roommate</H><audio>roommate.mp3</audio><PS>noun</PS><bracket>countable</bracket><D>a person that you share a room, an apartment, a house, etc. with</D>
<H>rude</H><audio>rude.mp3</audio><PS>adjective</PS><D>not polite:</D> <X>It's rude to interrupt when other people are speaking.</X><dot><X>You shouldn't be so rude to your parents.</X>
